messages.content: I'm sorry, but I couldn't understand your request. If you need help, you can use the `/help` command to see the available commands.

thoughts.subject: Conceptualizing a Generalized Snippet
thoughts.description: I'm focusing on crafting a single LaTeX snippet adaptable to any matrix size. My initial assessment of `math_other_snippet.lua` confirms a size-specific approach. The objective is to move beyond these limitations and devise a flexible, general-purpose matrix generator.

thoughts.subject: Identifying User Needs
thoughts.description: I've determined the user's request is likely a call for assistance. My next step is to formulate a clear, concise list of available commands. I'll prioritize clarity and brevity for ease of user comprehension.

messages.content: Soy un asistente de línea de comandos diseñado para ayudarte con tareas de ingeniería de software. ¿En qué puedo ayudarte hoy?

thoughts.subject: Designing Matrix Snippet
thoughts.description: I'm working on a versatile matrix snippet. The plan is to make it the go-to for all matrix needs. I will start by making the snippet flexible enough to accommodate user-defined dimensions as input. This will involve a new snippet to replace the older ones.

thoughts.subject: Formulating Snippet Logic
thoughts.description:
\n\n

I've parsed the file, and it's time to create the new, adaptable matrix snippet. I'm focusing on using a regular expression trigger, specifically `mat(%d+)x(%d+)`, to capture the row and column dimensions. Currently, I'm working through the logic of the snippet, ensuring that it correctly uses `bmatrix` environments and `insert_node` for each cell. This is a crucial step.

thoughts.subject: Coding the Snippet
thoughts.description:
\n\n

I've fleshed out the matrix snippet with its core functionality. The trigger is established and captures the dimensions. I am now building out the dynamic node using the captures, which will generate the `bmatrix` environment. The structure is in place and I'm focusing on the logic to correctly insert the `insert_node` elements. Each cell is assigned with the placeholder of `0`. I will test soon.

thoughts.subject: Integrating the New Snippet
thoughts.description:
\n\n

I've carefully reviewed the `math_other_snippet.lua` file and the existing matrix snippets. My strategy is to eliminate them and introduce the new, dynamic one. I am now prepared to implement the regular expression trigger, the dynamic node generation, and the `insert_node` placeholders within the code. I am focused on replacing the old, fixed-dimension snippets with the new versatile approach. I have also made sure to assign placeholders like `0` to the cells.

thoughts.subject: Refining the Dynamic Node
thoughts.description:
\n\n

I've worked out the code for the general matrix snippet and it's looking robust. The `mat(%d+)x(%d+)` trigger is ready and captures the dimensions. The dynamic node is designed to handle the row and column input, crafting the `bmatrix` structure. I'm now refining the logic of cell insertion with `i(count, "0")` and spacing the & and \\\\ characters.

thoughts.subject: Defining a Response
thoughts.description: I've considered the user's prompt, a simple greeting in Spanish. To answer appropriately, I'll specify my function: providing assistance. The goal is a concise, helpful response befitting a command-line interface agent.
